content:
This is a pretty hard clash, but what made it hardest (just got this in fastest mode) was the statement.

It wasn't clear to me that the 'n lines' of keys separated by spaces were the keys in each room from 0 to n - 1.

I'd suggest changing
<<The next n lines>>: The set of [[m]] keys in a room separated by spaces.

to 
<<The next n lines>>: The set of m keys in each room separated by spaces. Starting from room 0 to room [[n]] - 1.

I'd also change the constraints from having '[[m]]' to just 'm', since 'm' isn't actually a variable here, it's just the number of keys in each line. But that's a minor change.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The rules are quite simple, although solving it in less than 5 minutes might be tricky.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice!

One last thing, Test 5 has a key that to a door that doesn't exist (door 10). I would either mention some keys go nowhere/go to nonexistent rooms or remove that key (which unfortunately breaks the pattern).

Not enough approvals! We require more Clashes!
https://www.101soundboards.com/sounds/181970-we-all-need-some-good-old-fashioned-discipline

Looks like a good puzzle, I would suggest minor tweaks to the statement.

"and you have a key only from room 0."
->"and you have a key only to room 0."

"but you need to have a key to enter a locked room."
Implies there are unlocked rooms...pherhaps just add 
"A Magic Castle has n locked rooms" in the first paragraph.
Guess outputting '0' instead of 'YES' might be more clear and simple.
i think its a good concept but personally i hate story lines in cocs

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really interesting contribution just try to add more examples and it will be perfect!

Please consider changing binary output to something else, as per the specific guidelines for clash of code:
```
## Binary or language-specific outputs should be avoided in CoC.

Some output formats favor specific languages and make the contribution unbalanced. Binary outputs open the door to "cheating" solutions to get around 50%.
```
Ref: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines

(for instance what @Bartholomewlll suggested below)

- Boolean outputs are not recommended (true or false, yes or no). I would change it to print "yes" if you can visit all of them or to print the room numbers that you can not visit, sorted.
- Instead of "It has ..." say "A Magic Castle has ...". Not everyone reads the title (at least I don't :)).

Besides that, it's pretty neat!

Dear viewers, I am kindly ask you to express your opinion. If you do not like this contribution and going to downvote - would be very nice to know why and how it can be improved. If you are ok with it - please upvote to let me know that it is good. Kind regards!
It is my first contribution, so I am open to any hint and advices. Thank you folks!

Many thanks for such a detailed comment.
Regarding the first suggestion - it is interesting, but I am afraid to make it overcomplicated for the fastest mode, it should let users to solve in 5 minutes, so I would keep it as it is.
Th second suggestion also good - I have updated the statement correspondingly.
Many thanks for point me on that - the expected output and tests updated. Now cheating would not help, only real solution needed.
Updated first test case to make the example more clear.

Yes, I agree that I could write that one need to solve a DFS/BFS task checking accessibility of all 1st dimension entries in 2d array, having the further available indexes saved in 2nd dimension and considering that only first entry is accessible on start. But in such a case I was afraid it would be a bit boring.
Updated description and test cases correspondingly. Thank you for a good hint!
Valid suggestions - applied to the statement.

Since it is not a puzzle, but a CoC - we need to keep it short and simple, so I will fix the test to avoid confusion. I realize that such index can break code for someone who would use collection with static size(like array in Java). Thank you for your input! Test updated.
Many thanks Sir! Your input always was very clean and neat!
hmmm i understand the need of fun in cocs but i believe the fun is more in the coding and competing side than the problem statement

Instead of printing all the locked room numbers, you could perhaps print the number of locked rooms?

I still highly advise against boolean outputs because the player might solve a similar but different problem and not realize they're wrong until they submit (I just had that happen with an old problem that had boolean outputs).
